concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or anything you'd like to discuss.
client: Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling pretty alone since moving for grad school. It's hard to adjust with everything still being so shut down.
That sounds really challenging, especially with so many changes happening at once. How has this move impacted what you hoped for your experience in grad school?

It's made me question whether the whole moving away thing is worth it, you know? I was really looking forward to diving into my studies, but being isolated has been a big distraction and not what I imagined.
It sounds like the isolation is really weighing on you and affecting your grad school experience. What do you imagine would be different if you felt more connected or less alone?
I think I'd be able to focus better on my studies and maybe even enjoy the experience more. I'd probably feel more motivated and less like I'm just counting down the days until I can go home.
It seems like feeling more connected could really change your experience for the better. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel in finding ways to build that connection here?
Honestly, maybe like a 3 or a 4. It's just tough with the pandemic still making things weird, and I'm not sure where to even start with it all.
It sounds like building connections feels quite challenging given the current situation. What might move that confidence from a 3 or 4 to a higher number?

I guess if there were more opportunities to meet people safely or maybe if there was a way to connect with my classmates outside of academic stuff. Even just knowing where to find those opportunities would help a lot.
Finding safe opportunities to connect with others seems important to you. What would it look like if you felt more connected with your classmates outside of academic settings?

I think it would mean having more casual conversations or hangouts, like grabbing a coffee or meeting up for a study session that’s not strictly about coursework. It'd be nice to feel like I have friends here, not just classmates.
Therapist: Having casual interactions and friendships seems to be what you're aiming for. How might these connections impact your overall experience and well-being here?
client: I think it would make a big difference. Feeling like I have a support system would probably make living here feel less isolating and more like a second home.

It sounds like creating a support system through friendships could really enhance your experience. Based on what you've shared, possible options might include exploring clubs or groups that interest you or suggesting casual meetups to classmates. What feels like a good first step for you?
Maybe I'll try suggesting a casual meetup to my classmates, like a coffee break or something after class. Hopefully, someone will be interested, and it'll help break the ice a bit.

Suggesting a casual meetup seems like a great first step, and it's encouraging to hear you're open to initiating that. It’s wonderful that you’re considering ways to create those connections that can transform your experience here. Starting with a simple coffee break can really help in making things feel more comfortable and familiar. Remember, taking these small steps can gradually lead to building the support system you're looking for. Keep in mind that every effort you make counts toward reducing that sense of isolation. As you try this, we're here to support you along the way. Keep us updated on how it goes, and we can explore more options together if needed. You've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll give it a try and let you know how it goes. I'm a bit nervous about how they'll respond, though.

concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or anything you'd like to talk about today.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling kinda overwhelmed with my workload lately, like it’s non-stop, and I’m not sure how to keep up without burning out.

That sounds really challenging, and it's understandable to feel overwhelmed with so much on your plate. How do you envision your life looking if you managed to find a balance between your workload and personal time?

Honestly, I'd love to have a bit more free time to just relax or do something fun without feeling guilty or stressed about what I should be working on. Maybe go back to having a weekend day that's actually mine, like to catch up with friends or just chill.
That sounds like a meaningful goal to work towards, having that personal time back. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident are you that you can make some changes to move towards that balance?
client: Probably around a 4 or 5. I mean, I want to make changes, but it feels like there's so much to juggle, and I’m not sure where to even start.
It's great that you're considering making changes, even though it seems daunting. What do you think could help increase your confidence from a 4 or 5 to maybe a 6 or 7?

client: I think maybe having a more structured plan for my week could help, like carving out specific times where I don't touch work at all. Also, getting some support or tips on how to manage my time more effectively might boost my confidence a bit.

Therapist: Those sound like really practical steps towards creating more balance. It seems like having a structured plan and support for time management could really make a difference. What might be the first small step you could take to start exploring one of these ideas?

Maybe I could start by setting aside a couple of hours on one day this week where I don't do any work, like a mini-break to see how it feels. I could also look into time management resources or talk to some of my peers to see what they do to balance things out.

Setting aside a couple of hours for a mini-break and exploring time management resources or peer advice sounds like a great start. Would you like to set a specific day for your mini-break and identify a resource or person to connect with for time management tips? This could help you take those first steps towards the balance you're aiming for.

Yeah, setting a specific day would probably make me more likely to actually follow through, so maybe I'll pick Thursday since it seems like a good day to take a breather. As for the time management tips, I could reach out to that one classmate who always seems super organized and ask for some advice this week.

It sounds like you've got a solid plan lined up, and Thursday will be your dedicated time to take that well-deserved breather. Reaching out to your organized classmate for advice is a fantastic idea—it shows you're proactive about finding what works for you. Remember, it's perfectly okay to take time for yourself, and you're making positive strides towards balance. As we wrap up, know that I'm here to support you as you explore these changes. Let's touch base next time to see how your mini-break went and any insights you gained from your conversation with your classmate. You've got this!
Thanks, I really appreciate your support. I'll definitely keep you posted on how it goes.

concern:
Will be having my Master's Thesis proposal defense in the morning, and I'm all a bit tense and anxious and nervous and all the things that have going through my head. 

Been sleepy all day as if this is a way for me to cope with the stress it causes. Wish me luck everyone, good luck also to the countless graduate students who will be defending their own works!


Update: 

I cant believe it's done! I passed the proposal defence. Now I cant rest for a week from .

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. What's been on your mind lately or how can I support you during our time together?
I've just been so overwhelmed with everything going on, especially with my Master's Thesis proposal defense. It's been a real rollercoaster of emotions, to be honest.

Therapist: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed because of the pressure and emotions involved with your Master's Thesis proposal defense. Can you tell me more about what's been making it a rollercoaster experience for you?

client: Well, it's like one moment I'm excited and confident about my work, and the next I'm doubting everything and worrying if I'm on the right track. It's just a lot of ups and downs, and I feel like I'm on edge all the time.

Therapist: It must be exhausting to feel both excitement and doubt about your work. You feel on edge because these ups and downs keep you in a constant state of uncertainty. Can you share more about what specifically triggers these changes in how you feel?

client: I think it's mainly the feedback from my advisors and peers. Sometimes they praise my work, and that boosts my confidence, but other times they point out areas of improvement, and I start second-guessing myself. It's like I can't find a steady ground.

Therapist: It sounds like you're navigating a lot of mixed feedback, which makes it hard to feel steady. When you think about your goals and what's important to you, how does this feedback impact your motivation or vision for your thesis?

client: Honestly, the feedback sometimes throws me off track and makes me question my direction, but it also pushes me to refine my ideas and improve. I try to remind myself of my long-term goals, which helps keep me motivated even when the feedback is tough to hear.
Therapist: It's great that you hold on to your long-term goals to stay motivated. How do you envision your thesis contributing to those broader life goals you value?

I see my thesis as a stepping stone towards a career in my field, where I can make a meaningful impact. It's more than just a requirement; it's a way to develop skills and knowledge that align with my future aspirations.

Therapist: It's inspiring to see how you view your thesis as a crucial part of your future aspirations. Based on what you’ve shared, a potential goal could be to maintain your motivation and refine your work despite the mixed feedback. Would you like to explore specific strategies to keep your focus and confidence steady along the way?
Yeah, that sounds like a good idea. I definitely need some strategies to help me stay grounded and not get too caught up in the ups and downs of feedback. Do you have any suggestions?

Therapist: Absolutely, let's focus on strategies that could help you stay grounded. It's wonderful that you're open to exploring this. One approach could be establishing a routine that includes regular breaks and self-care activities, which might help balance the stress. Another strategy could involve setting specific times to review feedback so it doesn't overwhelm your entire day. Also, keeping a journal to track your progress and reflect on the positive aspects of your thesis journey could build confidence. It's truly commendable how you're dedicated to refining your work. As a next step, consider identifying one or two of these strategies to try out this week. Remember, progress takes time, and you're doing a great job by staying committed to your goals.
Thanks for the suggestions. I think I might try setting specific times for feedback and maybe start a journal. It could help give me some structure and perspective.

concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
client: Hey, thanks for having me. Honestly, I've been feeling a bit isolated in grad school. It's tough finding people who really get what it's like, you know?
therapist: It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of solitude at the moment. How does this impact your day-to-day life?
client: Yeah, it definitely affects my mood and motivation. Some days, it's hard to focus on my work or even feel excited about what I'm doing.
It sounds like it's really challenging to stay motivated when you're feeling isolated. What are some things you imagine might change in your life if you felt more connected to others?
If I felt more connected, I think I'd have more energy and optimism. Just having people to share experiences with or vent to would make the tough days a bit easier to handle.

It seems like you're looking for ways to build connections that could boost your energy and optimism. Based on what you said, possible options might include joining a study group or attending social events related to your studies. What do you think about trying one of these, or is there another approach that feels right to you?

Those are good suggestions, and I've been thinking along those lines too. That's why I started a GroupMe chat for other grad students—kind of like a virtual study group or social event. I’m hoping it'll help create some community vibes and make things less isolating.

That sounds like a fantastic initiative! Creating a GroupMe chat is a proactive step towards building that sense of community you're seeking. By fostering these connections, you're really paving the way for more energy and optimism in your daily life. Remember, it's perfectly okay to take things at your own pace and reach out when you feel comfortable. You're doing a great job navigating this, and it's clear you're committed to making positive changes. As you continue, keep in mind the importance of self-care and leaning on these budding connections whenever you need. Let's check in next time to see how this new approach is working and explore any further support you might need. You're not alone in this journey—I'm here to support you every step of the way.
Thanks, I really appreciate that. I'll definitely keep you posted on how things go with the GroupMe.

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. What would you like to talk about or explore together?

I've been really stressed about my future and figuring out how to stay in the US, especially with all the immigration and career stuff going on. It's just been overwhelming trying to decide if I should go for grad school or what my next steps should be.

Therapist: It sounds like you’re feeling overwhelmed because there are so many uncertainties with your immigration status and career path. What aspects of these options feel most important for you to explore right now?
client: I think the most important thing is figuring out the best path to stay in the US long-term. I also want to make sure I'm choosing a career path that I’ll enjoy and that’s sustainable.

Therapist: It seems like staying in the US and finding a fulfilling career are key priorities for you. How do you envision your life in the US when you think about having both stability and satisfaction in your career?

client: Honestly, I picture having a stable job that I’m passionate about, maybe in a field like data science, where I can keep growing and learning. It’d be nice to have some financial security and feel like I’m really part of a community here.

Therapist: It sounds like having a stable and fulfilling career in data science, along with financial security, is really important for you. How do you feel pursuing this path aligns with your values and what you truly want for your future?

client: I think it aligns well because I value continuous learning and contributing to something meaningful. Plus, being in a field that's in demand could provide more opportunities to stay in the US.

Therapist: It's great to hear that continuous learning and contributing to something meaningful are values you hold dear, and they seem to naturally align with data science. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about your ability to pursue this path and achieve these goals?
client: I’d say maybe a 5 or 6. I feel like there’s a lot I need to improve on, especially with my math and coding skills, and the whole grad school thing feels like a big hurdle.

Therapist: A 5 or 6 shows that you have some confidence, which is a positive start. What do you think might help boost that confidence and address the challenges like improving your skills and tackling grad school?
client: Maybe finding a mentor or taking some online courses could help. I think having a clear plan and some guidance would make things feel a bit more manageable.

Finding a mentor and taking online courses sound like promising steps to boost your confidence and skills. Based on what you've shared, possible action steps could include researching online courses in math and coding or identifying potential mentors in the data science field. What are your thoughts on starting with one of these options?
I think starting with online courses might be the easiest first step. It feels more immediate and I can do it on my own schedule, which is less intimidating than reaching out to a mentor right away.

That sounds like a well-considered choice. Starting with online courses provides flexibility and can gradually build your skills and confidence. What specific courses or platforms do you think you might explore to begin with?
I’ve heard good things about Coursera and edX, so I might start there. They seem to have a lot of beginner-friendly options in math and coding.

Therapist: Coursera and edX are excellent platforms, and it's great that you're considering beginner-friendly options. To create a clear plan, would you like to set a goal for how many courses you’d like to complete in the next few months? Additionally, we can talk about how you'll monitor your progress and what potential barriers you might anticipate.

client: I think aiming to complete one or two courses in the next three months sounds reasonable. As for tracking progress, maybe setting weekly goals or check-ins would help. I'm worried about losing motivation or getting overwhelmed, though.

It sounds like you have a solid plan with setting a goal to complete one or two courses in the next three months, and I appreciate your foresight in thinking about weekly goals and check-ins to help keep you on track. Remember, it's normal to feel a bit overwhelmed, and having these small, achievable steps can make a big difference. If motivation dips, perhaps celebrating small milestones along the way could keep the momentum going. You're taking meaningful steps toward your long-term career and residency goals, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. If you ever feel stuck, reaching out, even just for a quick chat, can be helpful. Keep believing in your ability to move forward with each step.
Thanks, that makes sense. I'll try to keep the momentum up with small celebrations along the way. If I start feeling stuck, I'll definitely reach out.

dialogue_conv:
therapist: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. What would you like to talk about or explore together?
client: I've been really stressed about my future and figuring out how to stay in the US, especially with all the immigration and career stuff going on. It's just been overwhelming trying to decide if I should go for grad school or what my next steps should be.
therapist: Therapist: It sounds like you’re feeling overwhelmed because there are so many uncertainties with your immigration status and career path. What aspects of these options feel most important for you to explore right now?
client: client: I think the most important thing is figuring out the best path to stay in the US long-term. I also want to make sure I'm choosing a career path that I’ll enjoy and that’s sustainable.
therapist: Therapist: It seems like staying in the US and finding a fulfilling career are key priorities for you. How do you envision your life in the US when you think about having both stability and satisfaction in your career?
client: client: Honestly, I picture having a stable job that I’m passionate about, maybe in a field like data science, where I can keep growing and learning. It’d be nice to have some financial security and feel like I’m really part of a community here.
therapist: Therapist: It sounds like having a stable and fulfilling career in data science, along with financial security, is really important for you. How do you feel pursuing this path aligns with your values and what you truly want for your future?
client: client: I think it aligns well because I value continuous learning and contributing to something meaningful. Plus, being in a field that's in demand could provide more opportunities to stay in the US.
therapist: Therapist: It's great to hear that continuous learning and contributing to something meaningful are values you hold dear, and they seem to naturally align with data science. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about your ability to pursue this path and achieve these goals?
client: client: I’d say maybe a 5 or 6. I feel like there’s a lot I need to improve on, especially with my math and coding skills, and the whole grad school thing feels like a big hurdle.
therapist: Therapist: A 5 or 6 shows that you have some confidence, which is a positive start. What do you think might help boost that confidence and address the challenges like improving your skills and tackling grad school?
client: client: Maybe finding a mentor or taking some online courses could help. I think having a clear plan and some guidance would make things feel a bit more manageable.
therapist: Finding a mentor and taking online courses sound like promising steps to boost your confidence and skills. Based on what you've shared, possible action steps could include researching online courses in math and coding or identifying potential mentors in the data science field. What are your thoughts on starting with one of these options?
client: I think starting with online courses might be the easiest first step. It feels more immediate and I can do it on my own schedule, which is less intimidating than reaching out to a mentor right away.
therapist: That sounds like a well-considered choice. Starting with online courses provides flexibility and can gradually build your skills and confidence. What specific courses or platforms do you think you might explore to begin with?
client: I’ve heard good things about Coursera and edX, so I might start there. They seem to have a lot of beginner-friendly options in math and coding.
therapist: Therapist: Coursera and edX are excellent platforms, and it's great that you're considering beginner-friendly options. To create a clear plan, would you like to set a goal for how many courses you’d like to complete in the next few months? Additionally, we can talk about how you'll monitor your progress and what potential barriers you might anticipate.
client: client: I think aiming to complete one or two courses in the next three months sounds reasonable. As for tracking progress, maybe setting weekly goals or check-ins would help. I'm worried about losing motivation or getting overwhelmed, though.
therapist: It sounds like you have a solid plan with setting a goal to complete one or two courses in the next three months, and I appreciate your foresight in thinking about weekly goals and check-ins to help keep you on track. Remember, it's normal to feel a bit overwhelmed, and having these small, achievable steps can make a big difference. If motivation dips, perhaps celebrating small milestones along the way could keep the momentum going. You're taking meaningful steps toward your long-term career and residency goals, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. If you ever feel stuck, reaching out, even just for a quick chat, can be helpful. Keep believing in your ability to move forward with each step.
client: Thanks, that makes sense. I'll try to keep the momentum up with small celebrations along the way. If I start feeling stuck, I'll definitely reach out.

concern: For context, I'm a chem PhD, defending in a few short months! I haven't published journal articles yet (working on 4 atm), the only thing I've published with my name is from conferences and MS thesis. I want to change my last name, but not sure how much this will impact the connections I've made over the last 6 years. Has anyone else changed or not changed their name ?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what’s on your mind or anything you’d like to talk about.

Hey, thanks for having me. I've been thinking a lot about possibly changing my last name, but I'm worried about how it might affect the connections I've built during my PhD. It feels like a big decision, especially with all the work I've put into my research and future publications.

therapist: It sounds like you're feeling a bit torn because changing your last name feels significant, given your hard work and connections in your academic journey. What are some of the thoughts or feelings that come up when you consider making this change?

client: It's like, on one hand, I really want my name to reflect who I am now, but on the other, I'm worried about losing recognition and how it might confuse people or affect my future career. It just feels like there's a lot riding on this decision, and I don't want to make a mistake.

It seems you're balancing a desire for personal authenticity with concerns about professional recognition. How do you envision your life and career might change, both positively and negatively, with and without making this change?

I guess if I change it, I'd feel more like myself and that could be empowering, you know? But then, there's that fear of having to re-establish myself professionally and the hassle of explaining it to everyone. If I don't change it, I avoid those issues, but I might feel like I'm not being true to myself. It's kind of a tough spot to be in.

It sounds like you're weighing the potential empowerment against the challenges of re-establishing yourself. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about navigating these challenges if you decide to go through with the change?

Hmm, I'd say maybe a 5 or 6. I feel like I could handle some of the challenges, but the uncertainty of how it might play out professionally makes me hesitate. It's a bit daunting to think about navigating all that.

therapist: It's understandable to feel that uncertainty, and acknowledging those feelings is a big step. What aspects of this change might make you feel more confident or bring that confidence number higher?

client: I think having a clear plan on how to communicate the change to my professional network would help. Also, knowing that there are successful examples of people who've done it might boost my confidence.

Therapist: It seems that having a clear communication plan and seeing successful examples could really support your confidence. What values or personal strengths do you think you could draw on to help navigate this change?

I think I really value authenticity, and that's why changing my name feels important to me. I'm also pretty resilient, so I like to think I can handle challenges, even if they're a bit intimidating at first.

Therapist: Your value of authenticity and your resilience are truly powerful strengths. Based on what you’ve shared, a possible action plan might involve creating a step-by-step communication strategy and researching successful examples for inspiration. How does that sound to you?
Yeah, having a step-by-step plan sounds like it could really ground me. Looking into examples of people who've navigated this successfully might give me a clearer picture of what's possible, too.

Therapist: It sounds like we've identified some important steps forward. By focusing on a communication plan and finding inspiring examples, you'll be taking strides toward personal authenticity while maintaining professional ties. Your resilience and authenticity will guide you through this journey. Remember, you're not alone in this process, and acknowledging the power of your strengths is a wonderful first step. As you move forward, know that you have the inner resources to navigate any challenges. The next step could be to begin outlining that communication strategy and gathering those examples. I'm here to support you all the way.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll start working on the outline and look into some success stories. It feels reassuring to know I'm not doing this alone.

concern: I am absolutely disgusted at how abusive my graduate professors have been, at least in comparison to my undergraduate professors. This seems to be way more common for graduate professors. It’s just so upsetting and hard to deal with.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm glad you're here. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind today—I'm here to listen and help.
Hey, thanks for having me. Lately, I've been really stressed out by how my grad professors treat us compared to undergrad. It's like a whole different world, and not in a good way.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the differences in treatment between grad and undergrad. What specifically has been stressing you out about this change?
It's just the constant pressure and lack of understanding. It feels like they don't really care about us as individuals, just the work we produce.
It seems like you're feeling underappreciated and pressured because you feel like just a number or a means to an end. Can you tell me more about how this pressure is affecting you personally?
I just feel burnt out and anxious all the time. It's affecting my sleep and honestly, I dread going to class or interacting with them.

That sounds incredibly challenging and tiring. You feel burnt out and anxious because the pressure is impacting your sleep and making you dread going to class. How has this been affecting other areas of your life?
Honestly, it's seeping into everything. I'm finding it hard to enjoy activities I used to love, and my social life is taking a hit because I'm just too drained to hang out with friends.
It seems like the pressure is impacting your overall well-being and enjoyment in life. What do you think might be different if this pressure were lifted?
I think I'd feel a lot more relaxed and like myself again. I'd have the energy and motivation to enjoy things and spend time with friends without feeling guilty or overwhelmed.
It sounds like you truly value feeling relaxed and being able to reconnect with activities and friends. What small steps do you think could bring you closer to that more relaxed state?

Maybe setting boundaries with my time could help, like trying to stick to a schedule that includes breaks and time for myself. I could also start saying no to things that aren't urgent or essential, to try and lighten the load a bit.

Those are great ideas that show you're focusing on what's important for your well-being. Based on what you said, possible options include creating a balanced schedule with set breaks and practicing saying no to non-essential tasks. How do you feel about starting with one of these options, and what might your first step look like?

I think starting with creating a balanced schedule could be a good first step. Maybe I could sit down and map out my week, including specific times for breaks and self-care, so I have a clearer picture of when I can breathe a little easier.

That sounds like a solid plan. Mapping out your week with specific times for breaks and self-care could really make a difference in how you manage stress. Remember, setting boundaries is a way to take care of yourself, and that's important. You’re showing a lot of insight and readiness to make these changes, which is wonderful. As you start this process, be kind to yourself and allow flexibility as needed. 

For this week, focus on creating that balanced schedule, and don’t hesitate to reach out for support if you need it. I’m here to support you every step of the way. Keep in mind, taking these steps is a positive move towards feeling more relaxed and connected with those activities and friends you enjoy. You're doing great, and I believe in your ability to make these changes.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll give it a try and see how it goes. I'm just worried about sticking to it and not falling back into old habits.

concern: As the title says my roommate doesn’t clean up after themself. Now our room isn’t a complete disaster and it’s mainly their side (plus our bathroom but it’s kinda 70/30 on who makes the most mess of it) but they just don’t really clean up. They have cups and cans and bottles all over their nightstand and desk and have even had a cup under their bed on the dresser before, and they’re never empty either. They also go home every weekend so they don’t really have dishes or real food here so they’re all Starbucks and Dunkin’ cups, so half full coffees just sitting there separating for weeks as they go home and come back. They do sorta clean it after a few weeks, I’ve seen them bag up the cups and other garbage, but they don’t take it out. They have bags full of garbage in the corner on their side of the room and our rooms not big so it’s starting to creep towards our closet almost in the way of it. As for the bathroom they leave hair everywhere and I know it’s theirs and not mine because it’s their little rubber bands with the hair. Now like I said I am also at fault for the the bathroom being messy but I try to keep it somewhat clean by taking out the garbage and have cleaned the shower drain but they don’t even try to clean up a bit. I don’t know how they don’t get embarrassed when they have a friend over or even just with me being here. I get embarrassed having 2 cans on my desk and a few dirty forks or spoons for a few days because I’m too tired to wash them yet. Otherwise they’re a good roommate it’s just they never clean. I should also say they had a single room last year so it definitely feels like part of the reason since they would be used to not sharing a space but I want to have friends over and I’m embarrassed for my roommate. I don’t really know how to tell them to take their garbage out without sounding like a bitch and I already accepted I’m gonna be cleaning our bathroom alone.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
client: Thanks. I guess I'm just frustrated with my roommate's messiness. It makes me feel uncomfortable in our space, and I don't know how to bring it up without causing tension.
That sounds challenging. How does this situation affect your daily life or your peace of mind?
client: It just adds a layer of stress I don’t need, you know? I want to relax in my room or have friends over without feeling embarrassed.
It sounds like having a peaceful and welcoming space is really important to you. What do you think might change for you if this situation were different?
client: If things were different, I think I'd feel a lot more at ease at home. It'd be nice to invite friends over without worrying about the mess or feeling like I have to apologize for it.
It seems like having an inviting space is really meaningful to you. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding a way to address this with your roommate?
client: Honestly, probably like a 4. I just don't want things to get awkward between us, but I know I need to say something.
Therapist: It takes courage to think about having that conversation. What might help bump that confidence up from a 4?
client: Maybe if I had a plan or some specific things to say that wouldn't come off as confrontational. I think knowing how to approach the conversation would make me feel a bit more prepared.

Therapist: Knowing how to approach it thoughtfully could indeed make a difference. What might it feel like if you were able to express your needs in a way that aligns with your values around maintaining a good relationship with your roommate?
client: I think I'd feel a lot more relieved and hopefully closer to them, like we can understand each other better. It would be great to just have that open conversation and keep the peace.
Therapist: Feeling relieved and maintaining that closeness sounds really valuable to you. How does this vision of mutual understanding fit with your overall goals for living together?

I really want us to have a comfortable and enjoyable living space, where we both feel respected and can have friends over without stress. It aligns with my goal of making our room a place where we both feel at ease and happy.
Therapist: It sounds like creating a peaceful and respectful home environment is very important to you. How do you see this goal influencing your next steps with your roommate?

client: I guess it means I need to start a conversation sooner rather than later. Maybe I could think of a kind way to bring it up, like suggesting a cleaning schedule or something that feels fair for both of us.

Therapist: Considering the importance of a respectful environment, initiating a conversation about a cleaning schedule could be a great step. Based on what you've mentioned, possible options might include setting a specific day to discuss and agree on a schedule, or writing down some ideas beforehand for clarity. What do you think could work best for you in starting this conversation?

I think writing down some ideas beforehand might help me feel more prepared and confident. Maybe I'll try setting a specific day to talk when it feels right for both of us, so it's not forced or awkward.

Writing down your ideas sounds like a thoughtful way to prepare and setting a mutual time for the talk adds respect and ease. How about creating a simple action plan, like listing out a few topics you’d like to address, and deciding on a timeframe to initiate the conversation? What potential challenges or obstacles do you foresee, and how might you overcome them?

I could see it being challenging if my roommate gets defensive or doesn't see the issue the same way I do. To overcome that, I think I'll focus on expressing how I feel and maybe emphasize the benefits for both of us, rather than pointing fingers or sounding accusatory.

You've put a lot of thought into this, and your approach really shines through. By focusing on expressing your feelings and highlighting the mutual benefits, you're setting a positive tone for the conversation. It sounds like preparing your thoughts and finding a good time to talk is a solid plan. Remember, it's okay to pause and regroup if the conversation doesn't go as you hoped. You're doing great by thinking ahead. Perhaps setting a date to revisit this topic can help keep the momentum. You're not alone in this, and if you ever need more support, we can explore new strategies together.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I’ll keep all that in mind and aim to handle it as calmly as possible.

It sounds like you have a solid plan, and I'm really impressed with your proactive approach. By preparing your thoughts and focusing on a respectful and positive discussion, you're taking important steps toward creating a more comfortable living space for both of you. Remember, it's entirely okay to take a step back and regroup if needed. You're doing a great job handling this, and I'm here to support you whenever you need it. Let's aim to touch base soon to see how things progress and explore any new strategies together. You've got this!
Thanks, I’ll keep working on it. Let's definitely catch up soon to see how things go.

{"reasoning":"The client has a clear plan to address their concern, focusing on preparation and respectful communication. They understand potential challenges and have discussed strategies to manage them. A follow-up has been tentatively planned.","determination":"move"}

concern:
As much as I like my work, I really fear my periods of break.  I am a CS grad student, so all of my works are done behind a few monitors.  Every time I take a break, whether it be for lunch or for once-in-hours break, once I start taking a break, I get so absorbed into it that I cannot get out of it. Most commonly, I watch YouTube videos (streams & stuff) during breaks because I don't know what else to do during the break and I find this activity the most amusing.  I have tried using a timer, but I tend to give myself extra few minutes over and over, and eventually not stopping, ugh! I also heard having a regular schedule might help, but I'm not sure how to set a regular schedule given that my work only involves research (no workout, nada) and it's difficult to get out of break in the first place.

I don't know if this is common, but I am the guy who gets immersed into work very quickly and likes to continue working straight, until my day's work gets to the end. Yes, I prefer work without breaks.  However, people say it's important to take breaks, and there is also some unskippable breaks like lunch and dinner.  What is the way to have a healthy break that does not break my work momentum?

Now, some may recommend working out, but I unfortunately am a "strong" at-home person and doesn't really like working out.  I think break should be giving me some dopamine, but workout should give me near-zero dopamine, while YouTubing gives me enticingly high amount of dopamine. Ugh, any suggestions for me, folks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
client: Hey! So, I've been having a hard time managing my breaks. Once I start, I just can't seem to stop and get back to work.
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling stuck once you take a break. What do you think makes it difficult to return to work?
client: I think it's because I get really absorbed in whatever I'm doing during the break, like watching YouTube. It's just so much more engaging than my work sometimes.
It seems like your breaks are quite enjoyable and engaging for you. What do you think might be different if you were able to balance your breaks and work in a way that felt satisfying for you?

client: If I could balance breaks and work better, I think I'd feel less guilty and more productive. Maybe I'd even enjoy my work more if I wasn't constantly worried about getting stuck in break mode.
It sounds like feeling less guilty and more productive is important to you. How might finding this balance impact other areas of your life or long-term goals?

client: I think if I can find that balance, I'd probably feel more in control of my time overall. It might help me build better habits and feel more confident about achieving my long-term goals, like completing my research without burning out.

therapist: Finding a balance seems crucial for you. Based on what you’ve shared, possible options might include setting specific break times or exploring strategies to make work more engaging. How do you feel about setting a small, achievable goal to start working towards that balance?
client: Yeah, I think starting small could be a good idea. Maybe I could try setting specific break times and see if sticking to them changes anything.

Great, I think you're on a promising path here. Setting those specific break times sounds like a really practical and manageable first step. Remember, it's about experimenting and seeing what works best for you. It's fantastic that you’re open to trying this out.

Implementing small changes like this can help you feel more in control and gradually lead to bigger shifts in your routine. If you find yourself struggling, maybe consider reflecting on how you’re feeling during these breaks and after them—this might give you some additional insights.

I want to acknowledge the effort you're putting into this; it's not always easy, but you're taking steps towards a positive change. Keep in mind, you're building a foundation for those long-term goals you mentioned, like completing your research without burning out.

As you move forward, know that I'm here to support you. We can check back on how this new strategy works for you and make any adjustments as needed. Take care and be kind to yourself on this journey.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll try to notice how I feel during and after breaks and see if it helps. We'll see how it goes, and I'll let you know if I need more help.

concern:
My 2 year program has a cohort of 30 people and I feel like I’m always finding out about gatherings after the fact. Last semester, I consistently saw Snapchat/IG stories and updates on bar hang outs, games, and more literally every week. Sometimes even more. But they were usually during or after the event. I tried to participate but how am I supposed to attend if I had no idea it was happening? And it’d get awkward when I was asking “what’s going on?” or “what are you guys talking about?”. Someone once even said “Poor (my name), she keeps thinking there’s a group chat for this when we plan it spontaneously”. I just get left out because no one tells me. I get that I’m more introverted, but I really do try to talk and participate in conversations and have been mistaken as an extrovert by an extrovert before. I’ve really worked on this over the years. And other introverts in the class somehow also find out about the events, parties, and gatherings. 

Part of me felt ok - I tried to make myself feel better by saying that those people just don’t have a life outside of the program. And that I wanted to have more of a balance. Seeing the same people 5 days a week a day PLUS some evenings and most weekends is a lot! On top of 5-6 classes and student clubs and volunteering, I have a GA position, casual job, serious relationship, family, and other friends to balance. I feel ridiculous and in the minority for feeling this way. 

Now that it’s March, there seems to be less of these events happening second semester, but it still hurts when someone sends a video or picture (e.g. group selfie) to the cohort group text and it’s like almost everybody is in it. This literally happened last night at 2AM for someone’s st patty party. I can’t silent the notifications or not check because sometimes there are important announcements to know. I try to shrug it off and not let it get to me but I feel ashamed that I’ve cried over this before.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! Feel free to share whatever is on your mind or any concerns you might have—I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, thanks. I've just been feeling a little left out lately, like I'm missing out on things with my cohort. It's been bugging me more than I'd like to admit.
therapist: It sounds like feeling left out is really weighing on you. What would it mean for you to feel more connected with your cohort?

I guess feeling more connected would mean actually knowing about and being included in gatherings. It might mean having more shared experiences and not feeling like I'm constantly on the outside looking in.
Feeling like you're on the outside can be tough. What do you think life would look like if you were more included in these gatherings and experiences?
client: I think I'd feel more like a part of the group, like I really belong. It'd be nice to be in the loop and have those memories to look back on.
therapist: Being in the loop and creating those memories sounds important to you. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding ways to become more involved with your cohort?
client: Honestly, I’d say maybe a 4 or 5. I want to, but it’s hard when I don’t even know where to start or how to change things.
It sounds like you're recognizing a desire to change but feeling unsure about the first steps. What might help you move that confidence from a 4 or 5 to a higher number?

Maybe just figuring out how to get myself in the mix more or finding ways to connect without feeling awkward. Maybe if I could have more one-on-one conversations or find someone who can clue me in on plans.
Building those connections through one-on-one conversations sounds like a meaningful step. What are some ways you might approach these conversations or find someone to help you feel more included?

I guess I could start by reaching out to a couple of people I feel more comfortable with, maybe ask them to grab coffee or something. I could also try to be more active on social media, like commenting on people's posts or stories, to slowly get more involved in their conversations.

It sounds like you have some creative ideas to start fostering those connections. Reaching out to people you feel comfortable with and engaging on social media are great steps. How do you feel about trying these strategies, and do you see any potential challenges?

I feel a bit nervous about putting myself out there, honestly. It's just a little daunting to initiate things when I'm worried about being seen as trying too hard or being intrusive. But I guess it's worth trying if it helps me feel more included.
You’re acknowledging the nerves and recognizing the potential reward of feeling more included. What might make initiating these connections feel a bit easier or more comfortable for you?

Maybe if I had some kind of "in" or shared interest, like a project or a mutual hobby, it might feel more natural to reach out. Or maybe starting with smaller groups rather than diving into the whole cohort at once could take some pressure off.

It sounds like you're considering some thoughtful strategies to ease into these connections. Based on what you've shared, possible options could include identifying a shared interest to discuss or starting with smaller group interactions. What would be a first step you'd feel comfortable trying, and how might you prepare for any challenges that could come up?

I think a first step would be to invite someone for coffee who I know shares a hobby with me, like maybe someone from my class who's also into photography. I could prepare by thinking of some topics to break the ice, so it doesn't feel awkward if the conversation stalls.

That's a great plan. You've put a lot of thought into how to make reaching out feel more comfortable, and it's wonderful to see you taking steps toward building those connections. Inviting someone for coffee who shares your interest in photography sounds like a meaningful way to start. Preparing conversation topics is a smart move to help ease any awkwardness.

Remember, it's perfectly normal to feel nervous, but you're showing courage by taking the initiative. As you navigate this, be kind to yourself. It's all about taking small steps at your own pace. 

Going forward, you might want to explore more shared activities or classes related to your hobbies. This can open up more opportunities for natural interactions. I'll be here to support you as you continue to build these connections and will check in with you to see how things are going. Keep up the great work, and remember you're not alone in this journey.
Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll give the coffee invite a try and see how it goes. It's a bit nerve-wracking, but I'm hopeful.

client: Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll give the coffee invite a try and see how it goes. It's a bit nerve-wracking, but I'm hopeful.
